bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to D.S. Lamb, October 24, 1927

div1.p: Kean thanks Lamb for information on Reed's last days.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to D.S. Lamb, October 24, 1927
div1.opener:
W Read II
Per. file
24 October, 1927
Dr. D. S. Lamb,
Poplar Hill, Maryland.
My dear Doctor Lamb:
div1.p:
Thanks for your note of Oct. 19th. Anything that relates
to Walter Reed's life, and especially the last days of it is of great
interest to me. You may have seen in the papers that I was sked to
give the address at the dedication of his birthplace at Bel Roi in
Gloucester County on October 15th. I made my address principally one of
reminiscences which, though relatively unimportant, have much human interest.

I have the printed report of the Memorial Committee of the
Medical Society of the District of Columbia after Reed's death, Dec. 31,
1902. I collected it and a number of other papers relating to Reed -
McCa's sketch of him, and a sketch which I wrote and the publications of
the Reed Board, and had them all published through the kindness of
Senator Robert Owen as Senate Document #322 of the 61st Congress, Third
Session, 1911. I expect you have a copy of this Document, which I constantly
refer to. When I get my address in print I will send you a copy..

By the way, your “Reminiscences of Old Medical Officers”
will come out pretty soon now in the Military Surgeon. I have it down for
the December number, but it is possible it may be crowded out by the
proceedings of the annual meeting in that number and have to go over to
January.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN,
Colonel U.S. Army Retd. JRK/B
